required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison Between Sonic Fill and X-tra Fill in Clinical Performance
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Performance of Sonic-Activated High Viscosity Bulk-Fill Resin Composite in Comparison to Conventional Bulk-Fill Resin Composite Restorations in Posterior Teeth: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Study.

brief_summary.textblock: The present study aims to evaluate a 1-year clinical performance of sonic-activated bulk-fill resin composite material (sonic fill) in comparison to conventional bulk-fill resin composite (X-tra fill) as posterior restorations. The null hypothesis is that sonic-activated bulk-fill resin composite restoration shows no difference when compared to conventional bulk-fill resin composite in clinical performance over 1-year evaluations based on clinical assessment.

primary_outcome.measure: change in clinical performance according to (USPHS) criteria
primary_outcome.description: restorations' evaluation using modified United States Public Health Service (USPHS) criteria for retention, color matching, marginal discoloration, marginal adaptation, secondary caries, surface texture, anatomic form. Score A (Alpha) stands for the clinically ideal restoration. Score B (Bravo) is a clinically acceptable situation except for secondary caries. Score C (Charlie) indicates clinically unacceptable restorations that must be replaced.

secondary_outcome.measure: change in post-operative pain using modified Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: The patients will be asked to record their pain level on modified Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) for 1 week.

intervention.description: bulk-fill composite resin restorations up to 5mm layer thickness

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- They should have an acceptable oral hygiene level.
- Presence of at least two posterior carious lesions to be restored with two different types of composite.
- The two materials should be used in approximately the same sized lesions or within the same extension.
- Age range between 18 and 45 years.
- A good likelihood of recall availability.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe or active periodontal or carious disease.
- Heavy bruxism or a traumatic occlusion.
- Patients with a compromised medical history or had received therapeutic irradiation to the head and neck region.
- Alcoholic and smoker patients.
- Patients had participated in a clinical trial within 6 months before commencement of this trial.
- Patients unable to return for recall appointment.
